title: Not all superheroes wear gray suits
text:
Boris Johnson likening Britain (and by extension himself) to the Incredible Hulk was pretty apt. The Hulk is, after all, an angry loner prone to bouts of extreme, senseless violence. But could Johnson have done even better with his choice of superhero? Take the Declassified quiz to find out. You have to decide if these are real superheroes from the Marvel and DC universes or, well, not that. Good luck. Scroll down for the answers.

1. Captain Britain

A. Alter ego of Brian Braddock. Endowed with extraordinary powers, Captain Britain is assigned to uphold the laws of Britain.

B. Nickname given to Dominic Cummings, Boris Johnson's senior adviser, by staff at the Department for Exiting the European Union.

2. Daisy Johnson

A. Boris Johnson's sister.

B. Aka Quake, a member of the underground movement Secret Warriors.

3. Rachel Johnson

A. Boris Johnson's sister.

B. Aka Shapeshifter, a member of the underground movement The Independent Group for Change.

4. Commissioner James Gordon

A. Gotham City police chief.

B. Ireland's member of the Romano Prodi Commission.

5. Andreas von Strucker

A. Member of Michel Barnier's EU negotiating team.

B. An enemy of the X-Men. Can fly and fire beams of concentrated plasma.

6. Andreas von Bonin

A. Brussels-based lawyer who works on behalf of Apple.

B. An enemy of the X-Men. Can fly and shoot thunderbolts.

7. Lady Ursula

A. A highly evolved brown bear and one of the Knights of Wundagore.

B. Nickname given to Ursula von der Leyen by staff at the European Commission secretariat-general.

8. Yellowhammer

A. Codename used by the U.K. Treasury for cross-government civil contingency planning for the possibility of a no-deal Brexit.

B. Alter ego of Darren Cross, the protégé of Hank Pym, who was the first Ant-Man.

9. Cliff Edge

A. Alter ego of Robotman, a member of the Doom Patrol team.

B. What Britain will fall off if there's no Brexit deal.

10. Hulkling

A. Nickname given to Brexit Secretary Stephen Barclay, as whispered in the tea rooms of DExEU.

B. Alter ego of Theodore Altman, a member of the Young Avengers.

11. Max Fac

A. An option favored by Brexiteers for solving the Irish border problem.

B. Former MI6 agent turned mercenary and assassin.

DOS AND DON'TS

DON'T: Buy David Cameron's book

According to "For the record," Boris Johnson lied during the referendum campaign and only backed Leave to further his political career. Tune in next week when we'll answer the question "do bears shit in the woods?"

DO: Enjoy toilet humor

Thieves stole an 18-carat gold toilet from Blenheim Palace in Oxfordshire. They're taking the piss/police have nothing to go on/ etc etc etc.

CAPTION COMPETITION

Can you do better? Email pdallison@politico.eu or on Twitter @pdallison74

Last week we gave you this photo.

Thanks for all the entries. Here's the top 3 (there's no prize except for the gift of laughter, which I think we can all agree is far more valuable than cash or booze).

"All EU need is Leave" by David Bell

"It’s been a hard Brex night" by Piotr Bartoszewicz-Malicki

"Baby you can drive my car (once fuel rationing is lifted)" by Robert Lewis

QUIZ ANSWERS

1. A

2. B

3. A

4. A

5. B

6. A

7. A

8. A

9. B

10. B

11. A

Paul Dallison is POLITICO's Slot News Editor
